{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3387854,"name":"Caden Feller","username":"BlackDiamond","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blackdiamond/{size}/165070_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T21:19:32.442Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone!

At our first (and last) competition some time ago, we were told that our robot was throttling the network on the field. That is to say, sending too much data through. We were using 4 cameras. Two were connected to the roboRIO for driver vision, and the other two were connected to a raspberry pi 5 that we were using as our coproccessor for computer vision. All 4 camera outputs were being streamed to the smart dashboard.

One of the volunteers told us that we were using too much bandwidth on the field and that we might need to lower the resolution or turn off all of our cameras. Sure. I was running the RPI5 at a pretty high resolution and framerate so I thought that was understandable. This was the team’s first time using vision processing, so its an honest mistake we had never run into. After our next match where the resolution and framerate were very low, we still were told that we were over the limit. I unplugged one of the cameras on the RPI5 as a hotfix and we were still just a hair over, so I ended up taking it out entirely.

Meanwhile, I saw other teams there that were using 4 orange pis for vision processing, each with their own one or two cameras, but they obviously weren’t violating the bandwidth limit. How is this possible? I don’t really understand where the bottleneck was happening, or what kind of limit I need to observe.

We are using a network switch to allow our coprocessor and RIO talk to eachther over network tables, and also be connected to the radio. Where exactly do they not want a lot of data throughput happening? My guess would be from the robot (and therefor their network) to the driver.

My guess is that if camera data is being streamed over network tables and never gets sent to the driver, 4 cameras won’t violate the limit, but can still run detection.

Is this correct?

Yes the problem is not the cameras, it is the streams to the DS. We run 3 cameras, but only stream 2 to the DS, and set the compression high. Last I checked, each stream used about 1Mpbs. Shuffleboard will display the bandwidth of each stream.

You are limited to 4 Mbps; that is megabits per second, really tiny compared to normal Internet limits.
